newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai copper ends up on speculation in March.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai copper ends up on speculation in March.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures ended up on Friday due to speculative buying of the key March 1997 contract in the afternoon, traders said.
The contract ended at 20,660 yuan ($2,489) per tonne, rising 230 yuan. It opened at 20,490, hitting an intra-day low of 20,470 and a high of 20,680.
December rose 120 to 20,120, January 210 to 20,420, February 200 to 20,630, April 170 to 20,650 and May 130 to 20,650.
Combined volume fell to 51,995 tonnes from 72,310.
Copper opened higher and rose for most of the session.
Traders said few investors wanted to hold short positions at current levels on expectations of further rises.
"Technical charts indicate further rises and expectations of a mid-term rebound boosted long position holders," one trader said.
Traders said that the London Metal Exchange is still an important factor affecting Shanghai copper in the absence of domestic market-moving news.
"Falling LME stockpiles encouraged long position holders in Shanghai despite heavy domestic spot copper pressure," a second trader said.
The spot copper price in Shanghai fell to 19,000 yuan from 20,000 during the past week.
Aluminium ended down. December fell 70 to 13,550 yuan per tonne, January 30 to 13,720.
Combined volume rose to 200 tonnes from 1,850.
